questions.question: Question 2: The intrapleural pressure is

options.d: Negative at apex but positive at base

questions.explanation:
Intrapleural pressure is usually negative. (normally -2.5 mmHg) During inspiration, it becomes more negative. (-6 mmHg). During forced expiration, contraction of the expiratory muscles raises intrapleural pressure to a 
positive value. Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the visceral and 
parietal pleura. 372 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: The intrapleural pressure is negative both during inspiration and expiration because

options.b: Thoracic cage and lung recoil in opposite direction

questions.explanation:
The intrapleural pressure is negative both during inspiration and expiration because the thoracic 
cage and lung recoil in opposite direction. The 2 factors that lead to a negative or subatmospheric intrapleural pressure are: • The lungs, with their elastic properties, tend to collapse, and the chest wall, with its elastic 
properties, tends to spring out. When these two opposing forces pull on the intrapleural space, a 
negative pressure, or vacuum, is created. • The continuous suction of excess fluid into the lymphatic channels. Applied aspect: In cases of pneumothorax, intrapleural pressure suddenly becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. 
Thus instead of its normal negative value, intrapleural pressure becomes zero. Hence lungs 
collapse and the chest wall spring out.

questions.question: Question 4: The intrapleural pressure (cm of H2O) at the beginning of inspiration is around
questions.explanation:
The normal intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration is about -3.4 cm H2O (-2.5 
mmHg). Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the lung pleura and the 
chest wall pleura. During normal inspiration, expansion of the chest cage pulls outward on the 
lungs with greater force and creates more negative pressure. At the peak of normal inspiration, it is about -8.15 cm H2O (-5.4 mm Hg). Note: 1mm Hg = 1.36 cm H2O 373 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: With reference to atmospheric pressure, what is the alveolar pressure at the end of normal 
inspiration (in cms of H2O)?
questions.explanation:
At the end of inspiration, the alveolar pressure is zero with reference to the atmospheric pressure. Whenever alveolar pressure equals atmospheric pressure, alveolar pressure is said to be zero. This 
happens when no air is moving in or out of the lungs. During inspiration, the diaphragm contracts, causing the volume of the thorax to increase. As lung 
volume increases, the pressure in the lungs must decrease. (Boyle’s law states that P × V is 
constant at a given temperature.) Halfway through inspiration, the alveolar pressure falls below 
atmospheric pressure (1 cm H2O). The pressure gradient between the atmosphere and the alveoli 
drives airflow into the lung. Air flows into the lungs until, at the end of inspiration, alveolar 
pressure is once again equal to the atmospheric pressure; the pressure gradient between the 
atmosphere and the alveoli has dissipated, and airflow into the lungs ceases. During expiration, alveolar pressure rises to about +1 cm of H2O.

questions.question: Question 6: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between
questions.explanation:
Transpulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure. (Mnemonic 
TAP: Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Pleural pressure) It is the pressure difference between that in the alveoli and that on the outer surfaces of the lungs, 
and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instant 
of respiration, called the recoil pressure.

questions.question:
Question 7: A man inspires 1000ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was -4cm H2O before 
inspiration and -12cm H20 at the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of lungs?(ml/cm 
H20)?
questions.explanation:
374 
Sold by @itachibot Compliance is change in volume per unit change in pressure. • C= V/P In this case, V= 1000 mL P= -12-(-4) = -8 cm of H2O The minus sign indicates that the pressure has fallen by 8cms of H20 at the end of inspiration Therefore the compliance is, C= 1000/8= 125 mL/cm of H2O

questions.question:
Question 8: A 22-year-old woman has pulmonary compliance of 0.2 L/cm H2O and an alveolar pressure 
of 4 cmH2O and an intrapleural pressure of -5 cmH2O at the beginning of inspiration. What 366 
Sold by @itachibot is the transpulmonary pressure (in cmH2O) when this woman inhales 600mL of air ?
questions.explanation:
The transpulmonary pressure would be 12 cmH2O when she inhales 600mL of air. Transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) is the difference between alveolar pressure (Palv) and intrapleural 
pressure (Pip). It is given by the formula: Ptp = Palv-Pip. Inspiration causes a negative change in 
both the Palv and Pip. Lung compliance is the extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit 
increase in transpulmonary pressure. In a normal adult, the pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O of both lungs 
together. Hence, expanding the lungs by 200 mL of inspired air will require an increase in Ptp by 
1 cm H2O. Given: Pulmonary compliance = 0.2 L/cm H2O = 200 ml/cm H20 Alveolar pressure at the beginning of inspiration = 4 cmH2O Intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration = -5 cmH2O Volume of air inhaled = 600mL (0.6L) Step 1: Calculate the initial transpulmonary pressure (Ptp). Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Intrapleural pressure; Initial transpulmonary 
pressure = 4 cmH2O - (-5 cmH2O) = 9 cmH2O Step 2: ˜se the lung compliance formula to find the change in transpulmonary pressure. Lung compliance = Change in volume / Change in transpulmonary pressure. Pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O. Hence, to expand the lungs by 200 
mL of inspired air, it will require an increase in Ptp by 1 cm H2O. So, for 600 ml inspired air, the 
compliance is = 600 mL / 200 mL/cm H2O = 3 cmH2O Step 3: Calculate the transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) after inhaling 600mL of air. During inspiration, the alveolar pressure (Palv) decreases, and the intrapleural pressure (Pip) 
becomes more negative. Final transpulmonary pressure = Initial transpulmonary pressure + change in transpulmonary 
pressure; Final transpulmonary pressure = 9 cmH2O + 3 cmH2O = 12 cmH2O. 375 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Compared to a gas-ventilated lung, a liquid-ventilated lung
questions.explanation:
A liquid-ventilated lung is more compliant compared to a gas-ventilated lung. Compliance is a measure of distensibility. In a gas-filled lung, surface tension and elastic recoil 
forces act to collapse the lung and thus reduce compliance. • When the lungs are filled with air, there is an interface between the alveolar fluid and the air in 
the alveoli; so, there is surface tension. • But, in the case of the saline solution-filled lungs, there is no air–fluid interface and there is 
no surface tension, making it more compliant. • Hence, the pressure–volume curve obtained with saline measures only the tissue elasticity. • The difference in the curves generated during inflation and deflation, termed hysteresis, is not 
present in the saline-generated curves.

questions.question: Question 10: The factor responsible for hysteresis is
questions.explanation:
Surfactant is the factor responsible for hysteresis. Difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–
volume curve of the lung is termed as hysteresis. The alveolar environment and, specifically, the secreted factors that help reduce surface tension 
and keep alveoli from collapsing, contribute to hysteresis. 376

questions.question:
Question 12: In the pressure–volume graph shown below, compliance of lung is represented by 
 
. Volume FRC Airway force
questions.explanation:
In the given pressure–volume graph: • A – Compliance of chest • B – Compliance of lung • C – Compliance of lung and chest wall The equilibrium position is at functional residual capacity (FRC), where the expanding force on 
the chest wall is exactly equal to the collapsing force on the lungs. FRC is also known as relaxation 
volume and represents the amount of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration. 379 
Sold by @itachibot At the point where volume= FRC, • Intraalveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure and considered as zero. • Intrapleural pressure is negative (-2.5 mmHg) • Transpulmonary pressure = Intraalveolar pressure – intrapleural pressure = 0 – (-2.5 mmHg) = 
+2.5 mmHg. For compliance of lung – Pressure considered is Transpulmonary pressure. So at FRC, 
Transpulmonary pressure is positive (+2.5 mmHg). Hence, B indicates compliance of lung. For compliance of chest wall – Pressure considered is intrapleural – atmospheric pressure. At 
FRC, this value is -2.5 mmHg. Hence, A represents compliance of the chest wall. When the volume is FRC, the combined lung and chest-wall curve intersects the X-axis at an 
airway pressure of zero. Hence, C represents the combined chest wall and lung compliance.

questions.question: Question 13: What is specific compliance of lung?
questions.explanation:
Specific compliance is obtained by dividing compliance by functional residual capacity. Types of compliance: • Static compliance: It is measured at rest. • Dynamic compliance: It is measured during breathing. It considers airflow 
resistance or impedance into account. It is maximum in medium-sized bronchi. • Specific compliance: • Lung compliance is volume-dependent. • It is greater at low lung volumes than at high lung volumes. For this reason, the term specific 
compliance is often used to denote compliance with reference to the original lung volume. • The total compliance of a normal person near the normal end-expiratory lung volume (functional 
residual capacity [FRC]) is about 0.1 L/cm H2O. • The compliance of the lungs is about 0.2 L/cm H2O. Applied aspect: In case of emphysema, compliance is increased but specific compliance decreases (because FRC is 
severely elevated).

questions.question: Question 14: Work done in quiet breathing is (kg-m/min)
questions.explanation:
Work done in quiet breathing is 0.5 kg-m/min. Estimates of the total work of quiet breathing range from 0.3 up to 0.8 kg-m/min. The work of breathing can be calculated from the pressure-volume curve. 380 
Sold by @itachibot The value rises markedly during exercise, but the energy cost of breathing in normal individuals 
represents less than 3% of the total energy expenditure during exercise. Applied aspect: In the case of COPD, airway resistance increases (obstruction to outflow). Hence, the patient 
should take slow, deep breathing. In the case of restrictive lung disease, viscous resistance increases. Hence, the patient is advised 
rapid, shallow breathing.

questions.question: Question 15: Work of breathing is mostly due to
questions.explanation: Most of the work of breathing is due to surface tension elasticity. Work of Breathing: • Elastic/Compliance work (65%): Surface tension (2/3rd) + Tissue elasticity (1/3rd) • Non elastic work (35%): Tissue/Viscus resistance (7%) + Airway resistance (28%) Work of quiet breathing = 0.3 - 0.8 kg-m/min Maximum work of breathing = 10kg-m/min

questions.question:
Question 17: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due 
to:

options.a: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
options.b: Difference in conc. of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
options.c: Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
options.d: Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.explanation:
The difference between the inflation and the deflation paths is called hysteresis. It exists because a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed 
airway, due to a deficit of surfactant at the air-water interface, than to keep an open airway from 
closing, as then it has abundant surfactant.

questions.question:
Question 18: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year old man who suffered a 
head injury in an automobile accident. Identify the pattern of breathing. 370 
Sold by @itachibot aprgț¡dMłe A •Æ!dsag Time (sec)
questions.explanation:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne–Stokes breathing. In this case, the person 
breathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not for an additional interval. 
This pattern repeats itself about every minute. It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heart 
failure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normal 
individuals. This increased response occurs apparently due to the disruption of neural pathways that normally 
inhibit respiration. In such an individual, increased sensitivity to CO2 causes relative 
hyperventilation, lowering the arterial Pco2. During the resultant apnoea, the arterial Pco2 rises 
again to normal, but the respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2. Breathing ceases, 
and the cycle repeats. 382
